docs.abstract: Federal regulators plan to begin considering rules that woujld end official ban on cellphone use on commercial flights; technical challenges and safety questions remain; if ban is lifted, one of last cocoons of relative social silence would disappear, forcing strangers to work out rough etiquette of involuntary eavesdropping in confined space; diagram; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Federal regulators plan next week to begin considering rules that would end the official ban on cellphone use in commercial flights....

byline.original: By KEN BELSON and MICHELINE MAYNARD; Stephen Labaton, in Washington; Matt Richtel, in San Francisco; and Christopher Elliott, in Orlando, Fla., contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: The day may finally be coming when you will be allowed to make calls on your own cellphone from an airliner. Trouble is, so will the passengers sitting on either side of you, and in front and in back of you, as well. Federal regulators plan next week to begin considering rules that would end the official ban on cellphone use on commercial flights. Technical challenges and safety questions remain. But if the ban is lifted, one of the last cocoons of relative social silence would disappear, forcing strangers to work out the rough etiquette of involuntary eavesdropping in a confined space.

headline.main: Cellphones Aloft: The Inevitable Is Closer

docs.abstract: Dell Inc reports net income of $846 million, or 33 cents a share, for third quarter ended Oct 29, up from $677 million, or 26 cents a share, in quarter year ago; revenue rises 18 percent, to $12.5 billion, from $10.62 billion in third quarter year ago (S)
docs.snippet: Dell Inc. said that its quarterly profit climbed 25 percent, propelled by an increase in technology spending by American businesses and a surge in sales abroad....
docs.lead_paragraph: Dell Inc. said yesterday that its quarterly profit climbed 25 percent, propelled by a steady increase in technology spending by American businesses and a surge in sales abroad. The company, the leading personal computer maker, said sales to the commercial sector in the United States rose 20 percent, ahead of the overall industry growth rate of just under 12 percent worldwide.

headline.main: Dell Profit Rises 25% as Sales Beat Growth Rate for Industry

docs.abstract: Cingular Wireless completes its purchase of AT&T Wireless after Federal Communications Commission signs off on $41 billion deal that creates country's largest mobile phone provider (M)
docs.snippet: The $41 billion deal will create the country's largest mobile phone provider....
docs.lead_paragraph: Cingular Wireless completed its purchase of AT&T Wireless yesterday after the Federal Communications Commission signed off on the $41 billion deal that creates the country's largest mobile phone provider. The F.C.C. approval came a day after authorization from the Justice Department, which required that Cingular sell some of its spectrum licenses in Detroit and Dallas, as well as some AT&T Wireless spectrum licenses and operations in 16 markets.

headline.main: With F.C.C. Consent, Cingular Buys AT&T Wireless

docs.abstract: A PeopleSoft director A George Battle testifies he was surprised by Oracle Corp's $7.7 billion hostile tender offer in June 2003, but not averse to idea, just to $16 per share price; says it was not much of premium over where People was trding; adds that when former PeopleSoft chief executive Craig A Conway responded to tender offer by saying he could not imagine price at which company would be sold to Oracle, he was being 'intemperate and over the top' (M)
docs.snippet: A PeopleSoft director said on Wednesday that he was surprised by the Oracle's hostile bid in June 2003, but not averse to the idea, just to the $16 a share price....
docs.lead_paragraph: A PeopleSoft director said on Wednesday that he was surprised by the Oracle Corporation's $7.7 billion hostile tender offer in June 2003, but not averse to the idea, just to the $16 a share price. ''It wasn't much of a premium over where PeopleSoft was trading,'' said A. George Battle, who is chairman of the search engine company Ask Jeeves. ''Usually when you want to buy a company and wrap it up quickly, you offer an attractive premium.''

headline.main: PeopleSoft Director Explains Rejection of Bid

docs.abstract: Oracle Corp co-president Safra Catz testifies she expects PeopleSoft's earnings will continue to drop, and while she suggests that Oracle might lower its hostile bid of $21 per share, she acknowledges that new price is not before board, trial, where Oracle has challenged PeopleSoft's anti-takeover defenses; at issue are competing claims of software rivals (M)
docs.snippet: An Oracle executive testified that she expected PeopleSofts earnings would continue to drop in the wake of Oracles hostile takeover bid....
docs.lead_paragraph: A co-president of the Oracle Corporation testified on Monday that she expected PeopleSoft's earnings would continue to drop, and while she suggested that Oracle might lower its hostile bid of $21 a share, she acknowledged that a new price was not before the board. A decision ''has not been made,'' she said under cross-examination by PeopleSoft's lawyer, Matthew Fischer, in the sixth day of a trial in Delaware Chancery Court, where Oracle has challenged PeopleSoft's anti-takeover defenses.

headline.main: Oracle Executive Tells Court PeopleSoft Offer May Be Cut

docs.abstract: International Business Machines supercomputer overtakes NEC Corp machine as world's fastest supercomputer; is based on technology that takes radically different approach from that used in Japanese computer; is one-hundredth size of NEC rival and uses far less power; will have wide commercial applications (M)
docs.snippet: An I.B.M. machine has reclaimed the title of fastest supercomputer, overtaking a Japanese computer that had caused shock waves at United States government agencies when it set a computing speed record in 2002....
docs.lead_paragraph: An I.B.M. machine has reclaimed the title of world's fastest supercomputer, overtaking a Japanese computer that had caused shock waves at United States government agencies when it set a computing speed record in 2002. Supercomputing technologies were widely viewed as indicators of national industrial prowess in the 1980's and 1990's. They are used extensively in weapons design.

headline.main: I.B.M. Supercomputer Sets World Record for Speed

docs.abstract: Computer Associates' former general counsel Steven Woghin will plead guilty to Federal criminal charges stemming from two-year probe into company's accounting practices; Woghin's plea is expected to clear way for prosecutors to move against former chief executive Sanjay Kumar and former vice president Stephen Richards, who have been focus of federal investigation; Kumar and Richards are expected to be indicted shortly; company and prosecutors also reach deal under which Computer Associates will temporarily accept outside monitor and pay restitution to shareholders in return for resolution of probe (M)
docs.snippet: Steven Woghin, the former general counsel of Computer Associates, will plead guilty to criminal charges....
docs.lead_paragraph: Steven Woghin, the former general counsel of Computer Associates, will plead guilty today in Federal District Court in Brooklyn to criminal charges stemming from a two-year investigation into the company's accounting practices, people close to the case said yesterday. The plea by Mr. Woghin is expected to clear the way for prosecutors to move against Sanjay Kumar, the company's former chief executive, and Stephen Richards, its former vice president for sales, who have been the focus of the federal investigation.

headline.main: Guilty Plea Seen in Computer Associates Case

docs.abstract: Some analysts say new competition from Chinese companies like Huawei Technologies is even more of threat to established telecommunication equipment makers like Nortel Networks than accounting scandals or depressed share prices; chief executive William Owens says Nortel's ability to compete will depend on getting its finances in order and further cutting costs; cites plans to bid for contracts to build and run communications networks; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Not only is Nortel Networks mired in an accounting scandal, it now faces increased competition from Chinese upstarts....
docs.lead_paragraph: Nortel Networks is mired in an accounting scandal that has led to criminal and securities investigations, numerous lawsuits and a purge of top management. But for its chief executive, William Owens, these may be the good days. As Mr. Owens struggles to restore the company's financial reputation while leading it through the latest round of staff and spending cuts, he is aware that another potential problem is lurking over the horizon: Aggressive and successful moves by Chinese companies into the telecommunications equipment market may soon force industry mergers and are likely to bring further corporate revamping.

headline.main: Nortel, Under Deep Scrutiny, Now Faces Chinese Competition

docs.abstract: Federal and state enforcement agencies have quietly arrested or charged dozens of people with crimes related to junk e-mail, identity theft and other online scams in recent weeks; cases are expected to be announced by Atty Gen John Ashcroft on Aug 26; nearly two dozen investigators work in office in Pittsburgh operated by National Cyber-Forensics and Training Alliance, nonprofit organization with close ties to FBI; much of financing for efforts, known as Operation Slam Spam, comes from Direct Marketing Association, trade group that wants to promote what it sees as legitimate use of e-mail marketing; graph (M)
docs.snippet: Federal and state law enforcement agencies have quietly arrested or charged dozens of people with crimes related to junk e-mail, identity theft and other online scams in recent weeks, according to several people involved in the actions.       The ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Federal and state law enforcement agencies have quietly arrested or charged dozens of people with crimes related to junk e-mail, identity theft and other online scams in recent weeks, according to several people involved in the actions. The cases, which have been brought by law enforcement offices around the country, are expected to be announced by Attorney General John Ashcroft in a news conference in Washington on Thursday.

headline.main: Junk E-Mail And Fraud Are Focus Of Crackdown

docs.abstract: Google settles patent dispute with Yahoo, move that reduces some of uncertainty surrounding Google's business as it prepares for initial public auction of its stock; settlement resolves lawsuit filed in 2002 by Overture Services, company that pioneered sale of advertising linked to Web search results; suit claimed that Google's system for selling advertising displayed next to its Web searches violated patent granted in 2001 to Overture, which Yahoo acquired in 2003; Google agrees to give Yahoo to 2.7 million shares, worth $291 million to $365 million if shares sell within range of $108 to $135 that Google has estimated for its initial public offering price; Yahoo will sell 1.1 million of those shares to public in Google's auction (M)
docs.snippet: Google said yesterday that it had settled a long-running patent dispute with its archrival Yahoo, a move that reduces some of the uncertainty surrounding Google's business as it prepares for the public auction of its stock.     Google's initial pu...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google said yesterday that it had settled a long-running patent dispute with its archrival Yahoo, a move that reduces some of the uncertainty surrounding Google's business as it prepares for the public auction of its stock. Google's initial public offering, once seen as a catalyst that could turn the slumping technology stock market around, has been delayed for about a week in the face of both technical snags and increasing investor skepticism. The unconventional auction could still proceed this week or early next week.

headline.main: Google and Yahoo Settle Dispute Over Search Patent
